I have some general info about the US-Mexico border that you might find interesting:  The United States and Mexico have about 1,989.61 kilometers (1,181.57 miles) of common land borders. The Rio Grande, which runs through the middle of Texas, is also the border between the United States and Mexico, though no other common border runs along a river. The United States Border Patrol manages the border, though the United States Department of Homeland Security, which oversees both the U.S. Customs and Border Protection and the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agencies, also has jurisdiction over the area. The US Border Patrol is responsible for policing the borders to prevent illegal immigration, drug trafficking, and money laundering. The largest drug- and human-smuggling routes into the United States and Canada run across the Mexican border. The United States and Canada currently have open border agreements with most Central American and South American countries to discourage human and drug trafficking. To help secure the border, the United States has been constructing the Border Fence (Barrio Alto–Campo Grande).
